tn.text: Paul and Sosthenes give greetings to the Corinthian church believers.
Unless otherwise noted, such words as "you" and "your" refer to Paul's audience and so are plural. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: Paul ... to the church of God at Corinth
tn.text: Your language may have a particular way of introducing the author of a letter and the intended audience. AT: "I, Paul, wrote this letter to you in Corinth who believe in God"

This indicates that both Paul and the Corinthians knew Sosthenes. AT: "Sosthenes the brother you and I know" (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: those who have been sanctified in Christ Jesus
tn.text: Here "sanctified" refers to people whom God has reserved to honor him. AT: "to those whom Christ Jesus has set apart for God" or "to those whom God has set apart for himself because they belong to Christ Jesus" (UDB)

tn.ref: who are called to be holy people
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "whom God has called to be holy people" Possible meanings are 1) "whom God has set apart for himself" or 2) "whom God has called to separate themselves from sin" or "whom God has called to not sin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Jesus is the Lord of Paul and the Corinthians and the same Lord of all the churches. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])
Paul describes the believer's position and fellowship in Christ as they wait for his coming.

tn.ref: because of the grace of God that Christ Jesus gave to you
tn.text: Paul speaks of grace as though it were a physical object that Jesus gives Christians as a gift. AT: "because Christ Jesus has made it possible for God to be kind to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Possible meanings are 1) "Christ has made you rich" or 2) "God has made you rich."

tn.ref: made you rich in every way
tn.text: Paul is speaking in general terms. AT: "made you rich with all kinds of spiritual blessings" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
God has enabled you to tell others about God's message in many ways.
God has enabled you to understand God's message in many ways.

tn.ref: the testimony about Christ has been confirmed as true among you
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "you saw for yourselves that what we had said about Christ was true" or 2) "other people learned from seeing how you now live that what we and you say about Christ is true."
"As a result"
"have every spiritual gift" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])

tn.ref: the revelation of our Lord Jesus Christ
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "the time when God will reveal the Lord Jesus Christ" or 2) "the time when our Lord Jesus Christ will reveal himself."
There will be no reason for God to condemn you.
"God will do everything he has said he will do"
This is an important title for Jesus, the Son of God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
Paul reminds the Corinthian believers that they are to live in unity with each other and that the message of the cross of Christ, not baptism by people, is what saves.
Here this means fellow Christians, including both men and women.
"that you live in harmony with one another"

tn.ref: that there be no divisions among you
tn.text: "that you do not divide into separate groups among yourselves"

tn.ref: be joined together with the same mind and by the same purpose
tn.text: "live in unity"
This refers to family members, servants, and others who are part of the household of which Chloe, a woman, is the head.
"you are in groups that quarrel one with another"
Paul is expressing a general attitude of division.

Paul wishes to emphasize the truth that Christ is not divided but one. "It is not possible to divide Christ in the way you are doing!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

Paul wishes to emphasize that it was Christ, not Paul or Apollos, who was crucified. This can also be translated in active form. AT: "It certainly was not put Paul whom they put to death on the cross for your salvation!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Were you baptized in the name of Paul?
tn.text: Paul wishes to emphasize that we all are baptized in the name of Christ. This can also be translated in active form. AT: "It was not in the name of Paul that people baptized you!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Paul exaggerates how grateful he is that he did not baptize more people in Corinth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
"only"
He was a synagogue ruler who became a Christian. (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
He traveled with the Apostle Paul. (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: This was so that no one would say that you were baptized into my name
tn.text: "I did not baptize anyone else because I was afraid that they might later boast that I had baptized them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This refers to the family members and slaves in the house where Stephanas, a man, was the head. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Christ did not send me to baptize
tn.text: This means that baptism was not the primary goal of Paul's ministry.

tn.ref: words of human wisdom ... the cross of Christ should not be emptied of its power
tn.text: Paul speaks of "words of human wisdom" as if they were people, the cross as a container, and of power as a physical thing that Jesus can put in that container. This can be stated in active form. AT: "words of human wisdom ... those words of human wisdom should not empty the cross of Christ of its power" or "words of human wisdom ... people should not stop believing the message about Jesus and start thinking I am more important than Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Paul emphasizes God's wisdom rather than man's wisdom.
"the preaching about the crucifixion" or "the message of Christ's dying on the cross"
"is senseless" or "is silly"
Here "dying" refers to the process of spiritual death.

tn.ref: it is the power of God
tn.text: "it is God working powerfully in us"

tn.ref: I will frustrate the understanding of the intelligent
tn.text: "I will confuse intelligent people" or "I will make the plans intelligent people make completely fail"

tn.ref: Where is the wise person? Where is the scholar? Where is the debater of this world?
tn.text: Paul emphasizes that truly wise people are nowhere to be found. AT: "Compared with the wisdom of the gospel, there are no wise people, no scholars, no debaters!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
a person who is recognized as someone who has studied a great deal
a person who argues about what he knows or who is skilled in such arguments

tn.ref: Has not God turned the wisdom of the world into foolishness?
tn.text: Paul uses this question to emphasize what God has done to the wisdom of this world. AT: "God has shown that everything they call wisdom is really foolishness" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Possible meanings are 1) "all who believe the message" or 2) "all who believe in Christ."
Here the word "we" refers to Paul and other Bible teachers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
"about Christ, who died on a cross" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

Just as a person can stumble over a block on a road, so the message of salvation through the crucifixion of the Christ keeps Jews from believing in Jesus. AT: "not acceptable" or "very offensive" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: to those whom God has called
tn.text: "to the people God calls"
"we teach about Christ" or "we tell all people about Christ"

tn.ref: Christ as the power and the wisdom of God
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "God acted powerfully and wisely by sending Christ to die for us" (UDB) or "through Christ God has shown how strong and wise he is."
Another possible meaning is that Christ is powerful and it is through Christ that God saves us.
Another possible meaning is that God shows the content of his wisdom through Christ.

tn.ref: the foolishness of God is wiser than people, and the weakness of God is stronger than people
tn.text: "what people call God's foolishness is really wiser than what people call wisdom, and what people call God's weakness is really stronger than people's strength" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
Paul emphasizes the believer's position before God.

tn.ref: Not many ... Not many ... Not many
tn.text: "Very few ... Very few ... Very few" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
"what most people would call wise"
"special because your family is important"

tn.ref: God chose ... wise. God chose ... strong
tn.text: Paul repeats many of the same words in two sentences that mean almost the same thing to emphasize the difference between God's way of doing things and how people think God should do them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: God chose the foolish things of the world to shame the wise
tn.text: "God chose to use those whom the world thinks are foolish to shame those whom the world thinks are wise"

tn.ref: God chose what is weak in the world to shame what is strong
tn.text: "God chose to use those whom the world thinks are weak to shame those whom the world thinks are strong"
the people whom the world rejects. AT: "people who are humble and rejected"

tn.ref: things that are regarded as nothing
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "that which people usually regard as without value" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: nothing, to bring to nothing things that are held as valuable
tn.text: "nothing. He did this so he could show that the things that are held as valuable are really worthless"

tn.ref: things that are held as valuable
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "things that people think are worth money" or "things that people think are worth respect" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"God did this"
This refers to the work of Christ on the cross.
These words refer to Paul, those with him, and the Corinthians. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])

tn.ref: Christ Jesus, who became for us wisdom from God
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "Christ Jesus, who has made clear to us how wise God is" (UDB) or 2) "Christ Jesus, who has given us God's wisdom." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Let the one who boasts, boast in the Lord
tn.text: "If a person boasts, he should boast about how great the Lord is"
